page.title: 15THE RIVER AVON AT WOODFORD
page.content: The{River Avon}is fifty to sixty miles long and about ten yards wide. It is a{chalk}stream; it rises in chalk but is not a very good example of one. It rises in the Pewsey Vale and flows almost due south entering the sea at Christchurch. The river is very rich in growth.{Birds}and{fish} breed well. There is abundant{plant} {life.}The river becomes polluted when farmers use fertilizer and chemicals, which also make the rushes and reeds grow more quickly. The level of the river is lower than it used to be. The fish in the river are mainly trout and grayling, a few salmon and other fresh water fish. When there are too many fish they stun them by putting an electric current through the river. Altogether this is a beatiful peaceful river.
